results.title: Makers of wine
results.brief_description: A survey of the Australian wine industry showing how wine is made, and some of the by-products which are produced in addition to excellent table wines. For wine grapes to grow well, soil and climate must be right; various types of soil are more suitable for some kinds of wine-grapes than others. In Australia, irrigation in the Murray Valley has helped the wine industry, for in many areas where wine is now produced, soil and general climate are suitable, but the rainfall is inadequate. Narrated by John Sherwood.

results.title: Make your senate vote count
results.brief_description: Bill Peach of ABC’s “This Day Tonight” explains how to vote correctly in a Senate election. In the last Senate election nearly half a million informal votes out of a possible 6 million, were cast and could not be counted. Tells the five simple steps to avoid mistakes.

results.title: Make way for ducklings
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Morton Schindel
results.brief_description: Animated story adapted from the book by Robert McClosky. Mr and Mrs Mallard are looking for a home. They finally choose a cosy place in the bushes beside a river in Boston, where their ducklings are hatched. One day Mrs Mallard takes her ducklings across to the park to meet Mr Mallard. Traffic is held up for them by friendly policemen.

results.title: Make a wish Molly
results.creator_credit: Phoenix Film Group, Betty L Spruill and Bruce R. Schwartz
results.brief_description: Molly has moved to California with her Russian Jewish parents who are proud of their heritage and culture. Molly is too young to appreciate her background and wants to be ‘normal’ like the other kids at school. She attends a friend’s birthday party but has to forgoe the cake because it’s Passover. Her friends find her clothes and hand-made present “funny”. Soon it is Molly’s birthday and her parents invent a way of preserving their heritage as well as embracing their new one. Designed for younger children, “Make a wish Molly” has something to offer everyone.

results.title: Make-up for girls
results.creator_credit: Goodman Memorial Theater, International Film Bureau, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds and Maurice Gnesin
results.brief_description: A young actress makes up as a young girl, Becky Thatcher, and as an elderly spinster, Aunt Polly, for stage presentation of Tom Sawyer. Authenticity of characters achieved by make-up demonstrates complete severance from the normal appearance of an actress. Base, shadows, rouge, pencil and brush lines, and lines of age and highlighting are clearly shown in practical, useful study.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Goodman Memorial Theater, International Film Bureau, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds and Maurice Gnesin

results.title: Make-up for boys
results.creator_credit: Goodman Memorial Theater, International Film Bureau, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds and Maurice Gnesin
results.brief_description: A young actor makes up as Tom Sawyer, a teenage character, and immediately follows with Muff Potter, the tramp of great age and general decrepitude. Shows how make-up, effectively handled, eliminates “type casting” and permits allocation of parts based on talent without need to consider physical similarities. Detailed steps from base to greying hair and whisker application covered.

results.title: Make-up
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television Overseas Training Films and Lawrie Lawler
results.brief_description: Considers the basic rules of make-up, which apply to black and white television production. Demonstrates cleansing, applying the foundation, shading, lighting and powdering. The special treatment of the eyes, lips, hair and hands are shown. Demonstrated by Laura Bradish.

results.title: Majorettes in space (E)
results.creator_credit: Haut et Court, Fidelite Productions, Little Bear, CDP, Simon Arnal-Szlovak, Carole Scotta, Stephanie Boussion, Olivier Delbosc, Marc Missonnier, Catherine Dussar, David Fourier, Francois Ozon, Pierre Salvadori and Bruno Rolland
results.brief_description: A collection of five gay shorts from France which inventively explore a myriad of themes from sexual diversity, notions of family, and the erotic correlation between sex and death. “Majorettes in space” (Dir: David Fourier) - using a rapid mixture of word association and seemingly unconnected images, “Majorettes in space” thematically links topics as unlikely as the Pope, cheerleaders, safe sex and space exploration (1996); “A little death” (Dir: Francois Ozon) - a gay man comes to terms with his own mortality when he learns that his estranged father is dying (1995); “One moment” (Dir: Pierre Salvadori) - through clever use of point of view and hand held camera we experience first hand a highly charged one night stand between two men which leads to a careless split second decision (1996); “Something different” (Dir: Bruno Rolland) - a low key comedy about the unlikely relationship that develops between a transvestite butcher and a little boy (1994); “A summer dress” (Dir: Francois Ozon) - a young gay man on summer holiday with his lover has an unexpected encounter with a woman while sunbathing nude on the beach (1997).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Haut et Court, Fidelite Productions, Little Bear, CDP, Simon Arnal-Szlovak, Carole Scotta, Stephanie Boussion, Olivier Delbosc, Marc Missonnier, Catherine Dussar, David Fourier, Francois Ozon, Pierre Salvadori and Bruno Rolland

results.title: Major league (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Morgan Creek, Chris Chesser, Irby Smith and David S. Ward
results.brief_description: The recently widowed, and new owner of the Cleveland Indians has a plan: field the worst team ever, watch the attendance fall, then move the franchise to glorious sun-drenched Miami. So she signs a punk-pitcher (Charlie Sheen), a gimpy-kneed womanising catcher (Tom Berenger), a third-rate third baseman (Corbin Bernsen), the outfielder Willie May Hates (Wesley Snipes) and a ‘wayout’ field of other crazy misfits. The perfect plan? maybe not, but it is the perfect ingredients for this riotous and inspiring comedy.

results.title: Maitre
results.creator_credit: Paris Cite Productions, Weston Woods Studios, Manuel Otero and Jacques Leroux
results.brief_description: This animated film is an abstract expression of the dilemma of the artist in his search for recognition. The source and process of artistic inspiration are explored as well as the artist’s reactions to his own failure and success. No commentary, music only.
